pullRequest.body:
This PR establishes various lemmas in the theory of permutation groups,
pertaining to the supports, cycle decompositions, and the conjugation action
of `ConjAct (Equiv.Perm α)` on `Equiv.Perm α`

This lemmas stem out PR #9359 and are used there to compute the cardinalities
of the conjugacy classes of permutations.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I've merged master.
The new linter fired up, so I guess you have to split the file in another PR and then we can merge this one.

What do you mean?
I have to cope with the new syntax, but what else is happening?

That the linter is saying
```
Mathlib/GroupTheory/Perm/Cycle/Basic.lean#L1: ERR_NUM_LIN: 2500 file contains 2311 lines, try to split it up
```
Note that I just kicked #10035 on the queue (I am not sure if it is relevant here).
I merged master and adjusted the files to the big split I had been led to do because `Equiv.Perm.Cycle.Basic` was becoming too big.

### PR summary [537b73a7cb](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9602/commits/537b73a7cbcc3d65b8babc01f11d0954a4eed3c1)

</details>

`+ ofSubtype_eq_iff`
`+ ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_mem`
`+ ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_not_mem`
`+ self_mem_cycle_factors_commute`
`+ subtypePermOfSupport`
`+ subtypePerm_apply_pow_of_mem`
`+ subtypePerm_apply_zpow_of_mem`
`+ subtypePerm_of_support_le`
`+ subtypePerm_on_cycleFactorsFinset`
`+ zpow_eq_ofSubtype_subtypePerm_iff`
`+ zpow_eq_zpow_on_iff`

bors r+

Can you please take into account my last comments? Thanks! (Feel free to merge it once done with those.)

bors r-
sorry to have missed your comments.

> sorry to have missed your comments.

No worries!

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

`Mathlib/GroupTheory/Perm/Cycle/Basic.lean` is getting super long and we should probably split it (in another PR), especially taking into account the [new linter](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Linter.20for.20large.20files.3F).

Thanks!

bors d+

```suggestion
theorem mem_support_iff_of_commute {g c : Perm α} (hgc : Commute g c) (x : α) :
```
Here `g` and `c` can be implicit, but keep as you think it is better.
I made them implicit
The sense of the double implication is swapped in the docstring wrt to the actual statement. Also, I would call it `mem_cycleFactorsFinset_iff`.
I changed the docstring and the name.
Also here `k` and `g` could be implicit.
Can you use `induction` instead of `induction'`? The latter sooner or later will be removed.
Yes. I did it throughout that file.
Here there a bunch of variables that can be implicit.
Yes. And the next one as well.
Same here for implicit variables.

```suggestion
variable [Fintype α]

/-- Restrict a permutation to its support -/
```

```suggestion
      exact hx

theorem cycle_zpow_mem_support_iff {g : Perm α}
```
oups
We usually use `induction n generalizing x` instead of `revert x; induction n <;> intro x`
That's indeed simpler; I'll adjust swiftly. Thanks!
Is it worth making this a simp lemma?

I have no experience about that. It looks like the right hand side is clearly simpler than the left hand side, which is of a very specific form, so that having this lemma tagged as simp should do no harm.
Let's try…

I assume this works:
```suggestion
  cases z with
```
This works, and I made the change, but what is the difference?
For a natural number `n`, `cases n` gives you two cases: `n = 0` and `n = succ a`, but in the second case you don't have the induction hypothesis.
OK, here it's for Int, but nevertheless, the disjunction between the positive/negative cases does not use any induction hypothesis, just a reduction to the case of nat.
What does "imp_lemma" mean?
It means I have to prove an iff, and I do that by proving the analogue theorem in the -> form (imp_lemma), and to prove the <- form, I apply `imp_lemma` to well chosen arguments.
an `iff` tactic would be nice.

This file is already too long. Do you think there's a reasonable place to split? That needn't (shouldn't) happen in this PR, but please think about it. In any case you'll need to merge master into your PR branch so you can adjust the list of exceptions.
I'll have a look and think at it.

@riccardobrasca had already asked for that (for another PR!). There are many sensible places to split this file, it does too many things at once. In particular, since it consists of 5 independent sections, each of them could constitute one file. 
And Basic.lean could just import all of them so that the rest is unchanged.
Please remove the lemma or the theorem before landing
I deleted it…
These comments seem superfluous; also in the next theorem
deleted
Probably `cases` works here too
yes.
I think we prefer `\subset` for `Finset`s
yes.

```suggestion
    obtain ⟨i, hi⟩ := hc.sameCycle (mem_support.mp ha) (mem_support.mp ((hgc' a).mp ha))
    use i
```
yes
This name doesn't read right to me. Would `commute_iff_of_mem_cycleFactorsFinset` be better?
OK.

```suggestion
  rw [Equiv.Perm.subtypePerm_on_cycleFactorsFinset hc]
```
Yeah, I should track my uses of `unfold`, I never know when Lean will recognize some stuff when it's not visibly there.

```suggestion
    · simp only [Subtype.coe_mk, subtypePerm_apply]
    · exact hx
  · intro h; ext x
    rw [← h]
    by_cases hx : x ∈ s
    · rw [ofSubtype_apply_of_mem]
      · simp only [subtypePerm_zpow, subtypePerm_apply]
      · exact hx
    · rw [ofSubtype_apply_of_not_mem, ← not_mem_support]
      · exact fun hx' ↦ hx (hc (support_zpow_le _ _ hx'))
      · exact hx
```

It's annoying you can't pass `hx` to `ofSubtype_apply_of_{not_,}mem` directly. Have you looked into why that is?
One can, but one needs to fill it a big share of the `subtypePerm`

```suggestion
    · exact ⟨rfl, rfl⟩
```
OK.

```suggestion
      simp only [IsCycle.pow_eq_one_iff hg]
```
I really don't think you're going to avoid choice with a tactical use of `dec_em`. Please just use `by_cases` or something like `obtain rfl|hm0' := eq_or_ne m 0`

```suggestion
-- Porting note (#10756): new theorem
```

```suggestion
theorem mem_conj_support (k : ConjAct (Perm α)) (g : Perm α) (a : α) :
```

```suggestion
    (ConjAct.toConjAct k • g).cycleFactorsFinset =
```
In that case I would leave them out of this PR, but save them somewhere. I guess they will remain in the big PR that depends on this one.
I can very well do that. In fact, I reworked largely the subsequent PR on #9359 and certainly many such lemmas are not used anymore.
I deleted those lemmas.
I'm not sure the comments here add anything
deleted. I also replaced `let` by `have`.

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Pointwise
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.ConjAct
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Cycle.Basic
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Cycle.Factors
import Mathlib.GroupTheory.Perm.Support
```

```suggestion
  simp only [Perm.ext_iff, subtypePerm_apply, Subtype.mk.injEq, Subtype.forall]
```

You could make this a little shorter with
```suggestion
  simp_rw [hc.commute_iff', Subgroup.mem_zpowers_iff]
  refine exists_congr fun hc' => exists_congr fun k => ?_
```

Ugh, this is annoying, but this works:
```suggestion
  · rw [imp_iff_right ha, ofSubtype_apply_of_mem (p := (· ∈ c.support)) _ ha, subtypePerm_apply]
```
I tried with these lemmas:
```lean
lemma ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_mem {p : α → Prop} [DecidablePred p] 
    {g : Perm α} {hg : ∀ (x : α), p x ↔ p (g x)}
    {a : α} (ha : p a) : (ofSubtype (g.subtypePerm hg)) a = g a := by
  apply ofSubtype_apply_of_mem
  apply ha

lemma ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_mem' [DecidableEq α]
    {g c : Perm α} {hg : ∀ (x : α), x ∈ c.support ↔ g x ∈ c.support}
    {a : α} (ha : a ∈ c.support) : (ofSubtype (g.subtypePerm hg)) a = g a := by
  apply ofSubtype_apply_of_mem
  apply ha
```
but `ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_mem'` is too specialized and `ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_mem` doesn't work
`ofSubtype_subtypePerm_of_mem` works if one gives it the correct argument `hg`. Thanks.

```suggestion
    rw [ofSubtype_apply_of_mem (p := (· ∈ s)) _ hx, Subtype.coe_mk, subtypePerm_apply]
```
I don't see a change in response to this
See below.

```suggestion
  · intro h; ext ⟨x, hx⟩
    simp only [Perm.congr_fun h x, subtypePerm_apply_zpow_of_mem, Subtype.coe_mk, subtypePerm_apply]
```
or at least `have` rather than `let`
This could go into the docstring
done.
Would it not make more sense to swap the sides of the iff, so the rhs is "simpler"?
yes. Done.

Finally, I had to revert on that idea, because it is a mess to adjust everything back to mathlib's syntax of `Equiv.Perm.subtypePerm`, 
```
/-- If the permutation `f` fixes the subtype `{x // p x}`, then this returns the permutation  on `{x // p x}` induced by `f`. -/
def subtypePerm (f : Perm α) (h : ∀ x, p x ↔ p (f x)) : Perm { x // p x } where
 …
 ```
Or this

The comment is tagged "pending", I don't know why, and it says that Cha ging the direction is a nuisance later on, because of mathlib's definition of subtypePerm, whose argument is precisely in this direction.
I managed to have it pass.
Ditto
In fact, maybe not: the issue, that appears later, is that the argument to`Equiv.Perm.subtypePerm` is written in this direction.
That was is left as is for the moment.

```suggestion
    constructor
    · intro a ha
      by_contra ha'
      rw [mem_support, ← h a, ofSubtype_apply_of_not_mem (p := (· ∈ s)) _ ha'] at ha
      exact ha rfl
    · intro _ a ha
      rw [← h a, ofSubtype_apply_of_mem (p := (· ∈ s)) _ ha, subtypePerm_apply]
```
done.

```suggestion
    · rw [h a ha, ofSubtype_apply_of_mem (p := (· ∈ s)) _ ha, subtypePerm_apply]
    · rw [ofSubtype_apply_of_not_mem (p := (· ∈ s)) _ ha]
```
Why is `hg` implicit?
I can make it explicit, but since it appeared in the goal, I had the idea that it could be inferred.
Ah that's possible. Do as you think it is more convenient.
Same.

```suggestion
  rw [ConjAct.smul_def, ConjAct.ofConjAct_toConjAct, Finset.mem_map_equiv, ← mem_cycleFactorsFinset_conj g k]
```
maybe this is too long.
I applied this; it takes two lines anyway.

```suggestion
  · rintro ⟨hc', ⟨i, hi⟩
```
Untested.

```suggestion
    refine ⟨fun h ↦ _, imp_lemma⟩
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: lemmas on permutations, cycles, etc.
